Justification: To check for signs of infection or inflammation, which could be contributing to the fever and seizures.
To rule out electrolyte imbalances, such as hyponatremia or hypocalcemia, which can cause seizures.
To rule out hypoglycemia as a cause of seizures.
To rule out meningitis or encephalitis, especially given the fever and recent upper respiratory infection.
To assess for any abnormal brain activity and help differentiate between different types of seizures.
To rule out structural brain abnormalities or lesions that could be causing seizures.
To identify any bacterial infection that could be causing the fever and seizures.
To check for urinary tract infection, which can sometimes present with fever and seizures in young children.
